title: Even Scarra's first thought about Neeko W was "a fuck you to Wukong"...
body:
He basically said that Neeko W reads as: "Fuck Wukong. it gives you a 3 hit passive, ms and the clone that moves in a direction."
But, I guess it was hard to give wukong a mini rework, had to make that cash money on a new champ.

replies.body: Of course it's a fuck you to wukong. She literally does everything Wukong does, but better.

What annoys me the most about this kind of an attitude is that, when players draw some similarities to existing kits (like LeBlanc and Wukong), this new champion is just a big "fuck you" to these players. Yesterday, i was reading how Neeko is basically LeBlanc 2.0 (because of the trickster thing) while today, i'm reading how Neeko's kit is more suited for Wukong and therefore, should've just prioritized them instead of her...

I'm glad the complainers aren't in charge of the game updates because no matter how you slice it, things are getting quite out of hand. So what, one champion even remotely occupies one design space and now, NOTHING NEW (an item, a rework, a new champ) can even show a similar mechanic, lest Riot be accused of banking dough from the new champion and their skins instead of just improving the older ones?

Get out of town...
When Riot reworked Galio and Aatrox, some people were vocal about them just leaving the old and bad designs in the game and making their reworks as NEW champions. Neeko isn't a Wukong/LeBlanc wannabe but since some players dubbed her that way, IT'S STILL A MISTAKE to have a champion in the remotely same design space as these two? 

What's the right option here?
It's bad to rework champions if Riot's going farther away from their original designs, it's just better to give a new champion that form. But when a new champion is made, that has a vaguely similar mechanic to the already existing (and poorly aged) champion, NOW the argument works in reverse - just make the old champion better, don't design a new one around that mechanic?
---
#???
#Where do these comically bad contradictions end?

I don't think that's the issue though, while I understand where your coming from. I think the players that are upset are that way mainly cause they always wanted better for the champion, only to have it ignored for years and years on end. Riot usually exclaims that they cant find a good design for that champ, yet they introduce a new mechanic that improves a already implemented design way better than the original.

Like for me when xerath players used to have to always zoom on the minimap to see who they were ulting. And bam, jhin comes out with a auto zoom feature.

Not saying your post is wrong, there are players that over exaggerate. But I think this is entirely why riot should focus on improving / reworking more than releasing new champions. Cause there new champions overshadow the other champions greatly

That's exactly why VGUs are still a thing.
Riot hasn't given up on older champions but it does take time to make them better, ESPECIALLY when even touching one with a 10 foot pole the wrong way will cause someone to REEEE out loud somewhere in the world.

And no, people can't just adopt the new mechanics and think that it's far better to scrap new champ designs in favor of the older ones. If  this mechanic was Neeko's thing from the start, Neeko isn't a terribly designed champion or even redundant because someone thinks that her mimicry (or W) is better suited for Wukong or LeBlanc.

I too see the similarities but i'm not here twiddling my thumbs, looking to chastise Riot for them having the audacity to make new and exciting champions because they're not cannibalizing every good idea and forcing it down an older champion's throat because it remotely fits them.

A hallmark of good design is to envision a final product, not throw scraps at the old one and seeing what can part can you glue to it to make it appear more functional than the OG version. They're not looking for a passable version of the champion, they need them to play good, feel good and look good after they're done with their design.
i'm still up to that old galio kit you know, or old poppy, those were good kits, for the one playing them.

You mean that Galio kit where he could deny magic burst for years, all from his abilities alone?

Yea, that was a "fun" kit to be playing against, as a burst mage.

well, shit, it ain't fun playing ashe vs rengar either, mate. 
it's called counterpick for a reason.

next argument its probably gonna be "rework adcs because they can kite juggernauts"

No, there are soft and hard counters theoretically.
League doesn't have hard counterpicks - those are the champions you know you automatically lose against and don't get to play League, if you pick a champion that can be countered easily even in champ select.

Assassins have ways of getting to squishies like Ashe but unless Rengar is fed, Ashe isn't losing to him the moment he's picked. And that's actually true for any fed champion, even tanks.

Old Galio was thematically way off with his design and his kit literally destroyed any hope for a magic damage user to even get an edge. Fighting him with or without any AP was never an option, even when he was getting ganked due to heavily ingrained MR and "heal-on-damage" MR shield. He acted as a hard counterpick to ANY mage. Meanwhile his AP scaled with his MR, which rewarded him for heavily investing in the anti-magic defense while mages would just have to give up on ever killing him in lane.
no his scaling on mr was shit, he only builded spirit visage and then full ap

The point isn't that he built MR for AP, the point was that he scaled from the only stat that was super hard against mages to get around, in the beginning of the game. His W was an even bigger MR buff for a few seconds + heal. 150-200 MR without a Void Staff or GV, was pretty easy for Galio to play.

Mages don't get to poke him or outplay him, they can't move him from the lane. So that lane become a farmfest against Galio.
